channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: British Police Arrest Former Guantánamo Detainee
item.description: Moazzam Begg is by far the most prominent of the Britons suspected of supporting jihadist groups fighting President Bashar al-Assad’s forces in Syria.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Pakistan Bombs Militant Area as Officials Weigh a Wider Offensive
item.description: The country’s cabinet was set to discuss expanded military action against the Pakistani Taliban and its allies after talks derailed this month.
item.dc:creator: By ISMAIL KHAN

item.title: Infighting Hurts Ukraine Efforts to Form a New Government
item.description: The lawmakers temporarily running the country delayed until Thursday the naming of an acting prime minister and a provisional government, underscoring the political differences among the three main opposition parties.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kiev on Monday lit candles and placed flowers in memory of antigovernment demonstrators who were killed last week in clashes with the police.

item.title: South African Judge Says Parts of Pistorius Trial May be Broadcast
item.description: Oscar Pistorius, the double amputee track star, had sought to block live television coverage, arguing that it would compromise his right to a fair trial.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: A Pakistani Militant Leader Stirs, Worrying the Indian Government
item.description: A recent speech by Maulana Masood Azhar of the militant group Jaish-e-Muhammad, after years of silence, adds to India’s concerns about rising violence in Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR
item.media:description: Maulana Masood Azhar, head of Pakistan's militant Jaish-e-Muhammad party, attending a conference in Islamabad, Pakistan, on August 26, 2001.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: In Beijing, Complaints About Smog Grow Louder and Retaliation Grows Swifter
item.description: Anger is rising over the government’s inability to protect the nation from pollution that has made places like the capital “unsuitable for human habitation,” as a prominent think tank stated this month in a study that was swiftly censored.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN
item.media:description: Visitors are silhouetted against thick smog at Jingshan Park near the Forbidden City in Beijing.

item.title: Camels Linked to Spread of MERS Virus in People
item.description: A study suggests that camels are the major source of the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, a viral disease that has sickened 182 people and killed 79 of them since it was first detected in 2012.
item.dc:creator: By DENISE GRADY
item.media:credit: National Institute of Allergy and Infections Diseases - Rocky Mo, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image of the MERS virus, seen at top, which belongs to the coronavirus family.

item.title: Japan Pushes to Revive Moribund Nuclear Energy Sector
item.description: The government of Shinzo Abe reversed course on a promise made by a previous government to phase out the country’s atomic power plants.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: India Ink: An Art Event Incorporates Itself in the Spaces of New Delhi
item.description: Insert2014 was envisioned as a way to allow people to actively engage with contemporary works in the public sphere.
item.dc:creator: By JYOTI PANDE LAVAKARE

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Magazine Cover for a Famously Humble Ambassador
item.description: In an interview with the Chinese edition of Men’s Health, Gary Locke, the departing United States ambassador to China, said he could hold a plank position for 51 minutes.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The cover of Men's Health features Gary Locke, and a challenge to readers.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Xi Visits Beijing Neighborhood, Lighting Up Social Media
item.description: President Xi Jinping continues his public diplomacy to a Beijing neighborhood, without donning a face mask on a day with heavy pollution levels.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG

item.title: India Ink: Leopard on Loose Paralyzes Northern Indian City
item.description: The big cat has attacked a police official, a TV news cameraman and four residents.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: A leopard leaping across a building under construction in Meerut, Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: China Accused of Firing Water Cannons at Filipino Fishermen
item.description: The Philippine military said the Chinese Coast Guard tried to drive away Filipino fishing vessels at the disputed Scarborough Shoal.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Gen. Emmanuel Bautista, left, chief of staff of the Philippine Armed Forces, with U.S. Ambassador Philip Goldberg on Monday at a forum of the Foreign Correspondents Association of the Philippines.

item.title: World Briefing: Mexico: Legal Wrangling Begins Over Drug Kingpin
item.description: Two days after Mexican marines arrested the drug kingpin Joaquín Guzmán Loera, questions are being asked about whether he will be tried in Mexico or in the United States.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: World Briefing: China: Beijing Rejects U.S. Move to Foster Tibet Talks
item.description: China will not recognize the United States’ appointment of a special coordinator for Tibetan issues, saying that it opposed any foreign intervention in its internal affairs.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Sri Lanka: U.N. Official Seeks International Inquiry
item.description: The United Nations’ human rights chief called for an independent international inquiry into possible war crimes committed during Sri Lanka’s civil war.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Vigilantes, Once Welcome, Frighten Many in Mexico
item.description: Some residents and businessmen, many of whom have provided support to so-called self-defense forces, are now worried those groups will turn on them.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD and PAULINA VILLEGAS
item.media:description: Vigilantes patrolled a road in Antúnez in the state of Michoacán, which was once terrorized by the gang known as the Knights Templar.

item.title: Mong La Journal: A Border City on the Edge of the Law
item.description: Mong La, Myanmar, draws Chinese over the border to gamble, as well as buy ivory and other animal parts, despite official disapproval of the casinos in China.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: At markets in Mong La, Myanmar, animal bones are widely available.

item.title: In Venezuela, Protest Ranks Grow Broader
item.description: In a coordinated action against the government, residents of Caracas and other cities have taken to the streets to protest a litany of problems that have long troubled the country.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Just Like His Power, Ukrainian Ex-Leader Vanishes Into Thin Air
item.description: Accused of mass murder, Viktor F. Yanukovych has disappeared, along with a handful of loyalists and perhaps his girlfriend.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: A wanted poster featuring the former president, Viktor F. Yanukovych, in Kiev on Monday.

item.title: News Analysis: Wary Stance From Obama on Ukraine
item.description: While George W. Bush was inspired by Ukraine’s 2004 revolution, Barack Obama has approached the unrest of 2014 with a more clinical detachment aimed at avoiding instability.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Israeli Warplanes Strike Near the Border of Syria and Lebanon
item.description: Israel has struck Syria at least three times in the past year, according to United States officials, to prevent sophisticated weapons from reaching Hezbollah amid the chaos of Syria’s war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Scottish Oil and Gas an Issue in Vote on Independence
item.description: Alex Salmond, Scotland’s first minister, who supports independence, and Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain, who does not, also differ on the future of oil and gas reserves in the North Sea.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE and STANLEY REED
item.media:description: An oil platform in the North Sea. London is arguing that it could better manage the oil and gas reserves there than an independent Scotland could.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Rash Repression in Venezuela
item.description: Venezuelans take to the streets to defend the very right to protest.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By FRANCISCO TORO

item.title: Amid Political Upheaval, Ukraine Faces Dire Need for Economic Help
item.description: The new head of the Ukrainian National Bank said one of his top priorities would be to secure aid from the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainians in Kiev on Monday lit candles and placed flowers in memory of antigovernment demonstrators who were killed last week in clashes with the police.
